talk.start.para: d asked the Prime Minister as Minister acting for the Minister for External Affairs, upon notice -

item.para: How many Japanese war criminals were convicted by Australian tribunals?
What was the nature of the offence, the penalty imposed in each case, and the date upon which the penalty was imposed?
In cases where terms of imprisonment were imposed and the full period of confinement was not completed, what was the date when the prisoner was given his liberty?
In what prisons did convicted Japanese war criminals serve their sentences?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: Six hundred and forty-four Japanese war criminals were found guilty by Australian war crimes courts.

The Japanese war criminals were tried for various offences, including murder and maltreatment of prisoners. Penalties imposed were as follows: - 148 were sentenced to death and executed; 275 were sentenced to terms of imprisonment ranging from ten years to life; and 221 were sentenced to terms of imprisonment of less than ten years. The trials began immediately after the end of hostilities and were completed in April, 1951.

Most of the Japanese war criminals sentenced by Australian courts were held at Rabaul and Manus Island until 1953, when they were transferred to Japan and placed in Sugamo prison. These war criminals were eligible for remission of one-quarter of their sentences for good conduct. A few other Japanese war criminals sentenced by Australian courts were held in Sugamo prison between 1945 and 1952 when it was under the control of the Supreme Commander for Allied Powers. They were treated by S.C.A.P. on the same basis as other war criminals held in the prison and were consequently eligible for release on parole after completing one-third of their sentences. After the Japanese Peace Treaty came into force in April, 1952, and control of the prison passed to the Japanese Government, the conditions of the release of war criminals held there on behalf of Australia were brought into line with the conditions applying to those held in Australian hands at Manus Island and Rabaul. In 1955 the Australian Government introduced a system of parole under which war criminals held on behalf of Australia became eligible for release on parole after completing the major part of their sentences. As announced by the Ministers for External Affairs and for the Army in July, 1956, the parole system was replaced at that time by a system of remission and release. This system was introduced to bring the treatment of Japanese war criminals held on behalf of Australia closer into line with the treatment accorded to Japanese war criminals by the United Kingdom, the United States, and other former Allied Powers, and under which war criminals were eligible for remission of the unserved portion of their sentences after completing a minimum of one-third of the sentence or a maximum of ten years' imprisonment. Since July, 1956, the remitting authority has been reviewing individual cases, and, as appropriate, granting remission of sentence and release. By now the release of all Japanese war criminals held on behalf of Australia has been authorized.
At Rabaul and Manus Island until 1953 and in Sugamo prison in Japan (see 3 above).

talk.start.para: k asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Transport, upon notice -

quote.para: In view of (a) the opinion expressed in the Report on Commonwealth Railways Operations for the year 1955-56 that the standardization of the railway between Broken Hill and Port Pirie should be proceeded with and (b) the completion of the railway to Marree releasing labour and materials, when does the Government propose to proceed with this important Broken Hill-Port Pirie standardization work?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows: -

quote.para: The matter of Commonwealth assistance for rail standardization is being considered as part of the wider problems of transport generally by the Cabinet Committee on Transport. The Government has accepted the recommendation of the committee that because of the very definite advantages which will derive from the standardization of this line work on the Albury-Melbourne section be undertaken as first priority. Some discussions have taken place between the Commonwealth and South Australia on the question of standardizing the railway between Port Pirie and Broken Hill. This matter is still under consideration, but no decisions have as yet been reached. The Government considers that the experience gained from the operation of the standard gauge line Wodonga-Melbourne will provide valuable information as to actual savings which can be effected by standardization.
